entry.title: Re: Is there any way to trigger the data update in tables...

Even with correct settings, if it is not working as expected, it could be due to:

In such cases, consider running program RMCBNEUA to force update, checking update rules in MC24, verifying update groups in MC26

entry.title: FB60 Duplicate invoices are not checked anymore
entry.content:
Hello experts,

In my system S4, FB60 Duplicate invoices are not checked anymore. before the check was working fine.

Now I checked, if the fields relevants for this check have been updated or changer, but it seems that there no way to change them, it's the standard behavior of SAP :

If the Reference Document Number field (BKPF-XBLNR) is filled up the following fields will be checked to idnetify duplicate invoices:

  • Company Code(BUKRS)
  • Vendor(LIFNR)
  • Currency(WAERS)
  • Invoice/Document Date(BLDAT)
  • Reference document number(XBLNR)

If the Reference Document Number field (BKPF-XBLNR) is not filled up the following fields will be checked to idnetify duplicate invoices:

  • Company Code(BUKRS)
  • Vendor(LIFNR)
  • Currency(WAERS)
  • Invoice/Document Date(BLDAT)
  • Amount in document currency(WRBTR)

Can you please confirm this ?

Now, what other points can I check ?

May be make a debug with a developer to make to check if there is a specific ABAP that bypass this check ?

 

Thank you for your help

Regards,

entry.content:
Hi @Dforway1 ,

In addition to what @Lakshmipathi and @GauthierVictor wrote.

Settlement Management – Transfer Manager and Split... - SAP Community provides some insight.

"reference doc (Sales Order) and reference item as split criteria" could result in a large number of items within a settlement document. Therefore I recommend the following:

  1. Test the worst case scenario (Largest number of items) early. Some years ago we tested settlement documents with about 200000 items. It worked. But every solution is different. The only way to find out if performance and usability are sufficient is testing.
  2. Avoid the derivation of fields from the reference document / item.

Regards,
Michael

entry.title: Handling CKEditor Content Sanitization and Formatting Issues in SAP Commerce SmartEdit
entry.content:
Background

SAP Commerce SmartEdit uses CKEditor for editing CMSParagraphComponent content. CKEditor includes sanitization logic that strips or modifies HTML tags it considers unsafe. If HTML is not well-formatted during in imported impex file  , SmartEdit may:

  • Remove content completely.

  • Alter the layout unintentionally.

  • Break visual rendering inside the editing UI.

Common Issues Observed

  • Special tags like <div>, <style>, or <script> disappear when editing a paragraph component.

  • HTML imported via impex with malformed tags (e.g., missing closing tags, extra <br> or  ) leads to distortion.

  • Changes made in SmartEdit on top of malformed HTML worsen the structure and cause further rendering issues.

CKEditor Sanitization Configuration

SAP Commerce allows limited control over this behavior using the following property:

 
cms.components.allowUnsafeJavaScript=true

Enabling this property allows SmartEdit to preserve certain script or inline JavaScript blocks, but this alone is not enough. If the underlying HTML is inconsistent or dirty, CKEditor still might misinterpret it.

Solution – Groovy Script to Clean and Beautify HTML

If a significant amount of CMSParagraphComponent content has already been maintained in a higher environment via Impex imports, issues may arise when a business user opens and edits that content through the SmartEdit editor. In such cases, saving the changes can distort the view of the content. This often happens because the imported HTML may contain formatting issues, such as unnecessary line breaks or improperly structured tags.

To address this, one option is to manually clean up the HTML formatting in each Impex file. However, a more efficient solution is to use the Groovy script provided below. This script exports all CMSParagraphComponent content from the higher environment, cleans up the HTML formatting, and prepares a clean Impex file that can be re-imported into the target catalog. Once the Impex is imported and the sync process is completed, the display issues in SmartEdit should be resolved.

Groovy Script :  

import de.hybris.platform.core.Registry
import de.hybris.platform.catalog.CatalogVersionService
import de.hybris.platform.cms2.model.contents.components.CMSParagraphComponentModel
import de.hybris.platform.servicelayer.model.ModelService
import de.hybris.platform.servicelayer.search.FlexibleSearchService

// Initialize required services
def modelService = spring.getBean("modelService", ModelService)
def searchService = spring.getBean("flexibleSearchService", FlexibleSearchService)
def catalogVersionService = spring.getBean("catalogVersionService", CatalogVersionService)
def commonI18NService = spring.getBean("commonI18NService")

// Define language and catalog context
def languageIso = "en" // Replace with desired language ISO
def catalogId = "abcContentCatalog" // Replace with your catalog ID
def catalogVersion = "Staged" // Replace with your catalog version

// Set the current language
def lang = commonI18NService.getLanguage(languageIso)
commonI18NService.setCurrentLanguage(lang)

// Get catalog version model
def catalogVersionModel = catalogVersionService.getCatalogVersion(catalogId, catalogVersion)

// Query CMSParagraphComponent items
def query = """
    SELECT {pk} FROM {CMSParagraphComponent}
    WHERE {catalogVersion} = ?catalogVersion
"""
def params = ["catalogVersion": catalogVersionModel]
def result = searchService.search(query, params)

// Print Impex header
println "INSERT_UPDATE CMSParagraphComponent;uid[unique=true];catalogVersion(catalog(id),version)[unique=true];content[lang=${languageIso}]"

// Process each component and beautify content
result.result.each { CMSParagraphComponentModel component ->
    def content = component.getContent()
    if (content != null) {
        def beautifiedContent = beautifyHtml(content)
        println ";${component.uid};${catalogId}:${catalogVersion};\"${beautifiedContent}\""
    }
}

// HTML Beautification Helper
def beautifyHtml(String html) {
    if (!html) return ""

    // Step 1: Normalize tag breaks
    html = html.replaceAll("><", ">\n<")

    // Step 2: Remove leading spaces on each line
    html = html.replaceAll("(?m)^\\s+", "")

    // Step 3: Clean up attributes inside tags
    html = html.replaceAll(/<([^>]+)>/) { full, inner ->
        def cleaned = inner.replaceAll(/[\n\r]+/, " ") // Remove newlines
                           .replaceAll(/\s+/, " ")     // Collapse extra spaces
                           .trim()
        return "<${cleaned}>"
    }

    // Step 4: Normalize inner text between tags
    html = html.replaceAll(/>([^<]+)</) { full, inner ->
        def cleaned = inner.replaceAll(/[\n\r]+/, " ")
                           .replaceAll(/\s+/, " ")
                           .trim()
        return ">" + cleaned + "<"
    }

    // Step 5: Re-indent HTML
    def indent = 0
    def lines = html.split("\n")
    def indented = lines.collect { line ->
        if (line =~ /^<\/.+>/) indent--
        def result = "  " * Math.max(indent, 0) + line.trim()
        if (line =~ /^<[^\/!][^>]*[^\/]>$/ && !(line =~ /<.*<\/.*>/)) indent++
        return result
    }

    // Step 6: Escape double quotes for Impex
    return indented.join("\n").replaceAll('"', '""')
}

What the Script Does:

  • Cleans malformed HTML tags and unnecessary line breaks

  • Fixes spacing and re-indents the content for improved readability and structure

  • Escapes double quotes to ensure compatibility with Impex format

Sample Output:

Here’s a sample output generated by the script in Impex format:

INSERT_UPDATE CMSParagraphComponent;uid[unique=true];catalogVersion(catalog(id),version)[unique=true];content[lang=en]
;AboutUsPageParagraphComponent;abcContentCatalog:Staged;"<div class=""container""><div class=""row small-health-container""><div class=""main__text-container header-text mt-10""><h3 class=""title mb-20"">Wherever you are on your health journey!</h3><p class=""description""><span>Dis-Chem goes beyond being just a pharmacy and retail store;</span>we deliver healthcare in various ways, extending our services, products, and initiatives to encompass community clinics, feeding programs the Dis-Chem Foundation, and health insurance products. With the momentum of initiatives like these driving Dis-Chem forward, we hope to lead a movement in South Africa, becoming the champions of better health for all. This shift in perspective allows us to see the bigger picture and take a more holistic view of health and wellness in today’s world. It aligns with the growth of our offerings, which we have developed and implemented over the years.</p><p class=""description mt-20""><span>Continuing to prioritize the bigger picture and adopting a holistic view of health and wellness will undoubtedly have a positive impact on our customers and the communities we serve. We are inspired by the opportunity to make a difference in people’s lives beyond the traditional role of a pharmacy and retail store.</span></p><div><hr></div></div></div></div>"

Conclusion:

CKEditor’s sanitization, while important for security, can interfere with business HTML requirements if the input content is malformed. Combining SmartEdit configuration (cms.components.allowUnsafeJavaScript=true) with Groovy-based content cleanup ensures your CMS content is resilient, editable, and production-ready.

entry.title: Re: Non-Nettable Warehouse Inventory Calculated in ATP
entry.content:
ATP in SAP ECC/S4HANA by default ignores the “nettable” indicator on warehouses and sums all unrestricted stock at plant level. MRP runs honor the nettable flag, but classic ATP doesn’t. In SPRO (or the equivalent SSCUI in S/4HANA Cloud) under Sales and Distribution > Basic Functions > Availability Check you can create/modify your Scope of Check, assign it to your Checking Rule/Checking Group, tick “No storage location inspection”. This tells the ATP engine to ignore storage-location stock entirely and only consider slocs entered on the sales order. Limitation: if no sloc is entered on the order, ATP still returns total plant stock (including sloc 04).

If you prefer a purely configuration-only approach, then, define an MRP Area type 02 for storage location 04. Assign sloc 04 to that MRP Area. In your ATP scope, restrict checks to all MRP Areas except the one for sloc 04. This isolates non-nettable stock but adds overhead on master-data maintenance and MRP runs.

The below comparison table will give a better idea

entry.title: How to Activate the Alert Management and Job & Automation Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM?
entry.content:
Hi Team,

How to we change the settings in the "Supported Use Cases" section of a system entry in the SAP Cloud ALM Landscape Management app? The "Job & Automation Monitoring" entry has configuration status "Inactive", and the "Alert Management" has status "Not Configured". How do we enable these settings? 

Thanks


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to Activate the Alert Management and Job & Automa...
entry.content:
If a system in the SAP Cloud ALM Landscape Management app has Configuration Status value "Inactive", it means that data collection was enabled at one point, but has been disabled and the SAP Cloud ALM backend still has collected data for that system. If you wish to move the status to "Active", you simply must enable data collection again for that system. More information can be found in KBA 3616000.

The "Alerting Management" statuses are dependent on the settings in the SAP Cloud ALM for Operations use cases. In order for "Alert Management" to show Active statuses, at least 1 Operations use case must have an event that generates alerts for the specified system. If no alerting has been enabled for a system, the use case "Alerting Management" will continue to show status "Not Configured". You spoke about Job & Automation Monitoring, so you can follow KBA 3111904 to help configure Alerting for that use case.

entry.title: Re: SAC Odata Service Connection Failed
Re: FB60 Duplicate invoices are not checked anymore
entry.content:
By design, the FI duplicate-invoice check in FB60 (and F-43/MIRO) uses the following fields:

When Reference Number (BKPF–XBLNR) is filled, it checks Company Code (BUKRS) • Vendor (LIFNR) • Currency (WAERS) • Invoice/Document Date (BLDAT) • Reference Document Number (XBLNR)

When Reference Number is blank it checks Company Code (BUKRS) • Vendor (LIFNR) • Currency (WAERS) • Invoice/Document Date (BLDAT) • Amount in Document Currency (WRBTR).

Use transaction BP (or FK02 for classic vendor master) → role FLVN00 → Payment Transactions view → ensure Check double inv. (LFB1–REPRF) is selected. If this flag is off, FB60 skips the duplicate check.

Go to SPRO → Financial Accounting Global Settings → Document → Default Values for Document Processing → Change Message Control for Document Processing. Under Application Area F5 (General Data) and M8 (Transactional Data), locate message F5 117. Ensure it’s set as a warning or error, not “blank.” If it’s blank, SAP won’t intervene—even if the FM finds a duplicate.

Open transaction OB41, select the posting key used by FB60 (e.g., 21). Check the “Sales-related posting” indicator. Only posting keys flagged here trigger the duplicate-invoice logic.

entry.title: Re: Reduce height of combo box drop down
entry.content:
Hi,

For sap.m.ComboBox, there are some sap build in css capabilty.

You can use this "sapMComboBoxList" sap ui5 standard css class to reduce height of your comboBox. Note: size 30 rem will show you 10 items at a time and rest items by scrolling. If you use sap.m.Select you need upgrade it to sap.m.ComboBox, as this is for holding long list of items.

.sapMComboBoxList {
max-height: 30rem;
scroll-behavior: smooth;
}

Also if you use sap.m.MultiComboBox then use the below sap ui5 standard css class :

.sapMListItems {
max-height: 20rem;
}

I have implemented this approach to reduce the height of dropdown in sap ui5. It was really challenging to figure out this approach.

Thanks,

Shobhit Srivastava

SAP BTP developer

entry.title: How to Design Low-Fidelity Dashboards with the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit
entry.content:
Focus of this blog:

  • Intro
  • How the library is set up
  • How to get the library
  • How to use the library
  • How to work efficiently with the library

 

Intro

Effective dashboard design begins with user research. Gathering and understanding the necessary insights of your end-users' needs and requirements ensures high-quality experience. Jumping straight into creating high-fidelity mockups or even building dashboards directly in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories can create unnecessary distraction and slow down your design process.

👉Learn how to build better dashboards here.

Instead, start with scribbles and rough sketches. Early in the process, low-fidelity mockups help you explore ideas quickly, collect feedback, and align on structure and meaningful insights before refining visual details.

That’s why we created the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit for Figma. It helps you transform your ideas seamlessly into digital low-fidelity designs.

The library offers basic layouts and provides components to help you design and iterate quickly, without distraction, ensuring you can focus on what matters: content, flow, and meaningful Insights. It helps you to speed up your design process, share clear ideas, review them with your team, and get feedback from stakeholders.

 

 

How the library is set up

The library consists of three pages, which allows for easy navigation and usage.

The first page, “📓 Cover“, is a library overview that includes a cover, a version history and slides explaining the purpose and usage of the library.

 

The second page, “✏️ Analytical Pages”, provides dashboard templates. Depending on the purpose of your dashboard, you can choose to use different BI page types, or start with an empty page to design your dashboard from scratch.

 

The third page, “✏️ Components”, contains all other assets: UI elements and controls, containers and different chart types available in SAP Analytics Cloud stories.

 

 

How to get the library

You can simply download the library from GitHub.

Opening the file will import it into Figma. Just choose a folder, and you're ready to go.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

👉Download the SAC Dashboard Schematics UI Kit on GitHub.

 

 

How to use the library

We recommend publishing the library internally in your company's Figma space after importing the file to make use of Figma’s Library functionality. This means, that based on your settings, your direct team or your whole organization can access the library through the asset panel, enabling smooth collaboration and consistent usage across your design teams.

To publish a library, open the File Settings, navigate to “Library” and click on “Publish Library...”. Select the components you want to publish and specify who can access the library. Click on "Publish" and it's done.

Note: This option won't work if the file has been imported into your Drafts.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Now you can add the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit to your files through the libraries dialog and access all components directly from the assets panel.

If you don’t want to publish the library internally, you can simply copy and paste the components into your own design files or use them as local assets.

 

 

How to work efficiently with the library

To get started, we’ve created a short introduction video that demonstrates how to build a dashboard using the library.

 

 

You can follow one of two possible workflows:

1. Start with an analytical page type

Open a new file and navigate to the assets panel. Drag an instance into your canvas, e.g. a "Monitoring Page".

In the design panel, you can see the different options you have for each instance. The "Monitoring Page" can use the visual type “Placeholder” (default) or “Content”. Switching to “Content” will present basic charts.

 

Most components are nested within each other. This means you can simply select individual parts of an instance to get additional options in the design panel. This makes it easy to adjust the layout to fit your specific needs.

 

 

2. Start from scratch

Open a new file and either create a new frame or navigate to the assets panel to drag an "Empty Page" into your canvas. If you use the "Empty Page", you can detach the instance to freely use and customize the frame.

 

Browse or search for the containers you want to use, e.g. a header and multiple panels or cards, and drag them into your frame.

 

Set "Visual Type" to “Content” to show charts.

 

 

 

Feel free to share any feedback, ideas, questions, or requests regarding our SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit in the comments below.

And check out our Dashboard Design Best-Practices blog series that was created to assist you in designing and building meaningful dashboards with SAP Analytics Cloud.

👉Open the Best-Practices Blog Series.

entry.title: INSERT/DELETE data in exposed CDS entities via ODBC
entry.content:
In previous blog posts (see links at the end), I described data integration scenarios where business users can access data in an ABAP system from an external consumer, using the ABAP SQL service and the ODBC driver for ABAP. In this scenario, can query data in exposed CDS view entities. So far, this was a read-only scenario, where SELECT statements were used.

Now, with the availability of writable CDS view entities, the SQL service can also be used to change data in an ABAP system. The first supported SQL DML statements that allow to change data in an SAP system using the ABAP SQL service are INSERT and DELETE.

In this blog post, I will describe an example where a writable ABAP CDS view entity is exposed, I will describe the supported INSERT and DELETE statement types and their restrictions, and provide a code sample that uses those statements on an exposed entity.

Prerequisites:

  • ABAP platform cloud 2508 or ABAP on-premise 2025 or higher
  • ODBC driver for ABAP version 01, or higher

The steps to expose a writable view entity are very similar to the steps described in this blog post for read-only entities. I will try to keep the description in this blog post similar and only outline the differences for writable CDS view entities.

Create a Writable CDS View Entity on Top of a Table

First, I create a test table for this blog post and a writable CDS view entity on top of it. In my case, the writable view entity is a simple projection of a database test table containing all table columns.

@EndUserText.label : 'test table for SQL Service DMLs'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zsql_write_tab {
  key client : abap.clnt not null;
  key itemnr : abap.int4 not null;
  key idate  : abap.datn not null;
  @AbapCatalog.decfloat.outputStyle : #NORMAL
  amount     : abap.decfloat34;
}

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'writable view entity for SQL service'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
  serviceQuality: #X,
  sizeCategory: #S,
  dataClass: #MIXED
}
define writable view entity ZSQL_WRITE_VIEW
  as select from zsql_write_tab as TestTable
{
  key itemnr as ItemNr,
  key idate  as IDate,
  amount     as Amount
}

Create a service definition and binding containing the writable CDS view entity

As a second step, define a service definition exposing the writable view entity:

@EndUserText.label: 'service def with writable view entity'

define service ZWRITE
  provider contracts sql {
  expose ZSQL_WRITE_VIEW as WriteView;
}

I create a service binding with the same name as the service definition and enable operations. Please note that I enabled operations SELECT, INSERT, and DELETE for this service binding:

 

Configure Privileged User Access with INSERT and DELETE Operations

Next, I define the user access to the writable CDS view entities. Again, the configuration of privileged user access has already been described in this blog post for a cloud system, or you can refer to the onprem documentation. INSERT and DELETE statements are currently only allowed for privileged user access.

So, essentially, you can follow the previous blog post. The only difference is that you now need to add INSERT and DELETE as allowed SQL view operations to the S_SQL_VIEW authorization object, for example, with the following properties.

SQL_SCHEMA -> ZWRITE
SQL_VIEW -> *
SQL_VIEWOP -> SELECT, INSERT, DELETE

Now, everything is set up to execute queries and INSERT and DELETE statements on our test entity.
I won’t repeat the description of how to install and configure the ODBC driver for ABAP here and for the next steps I will just assume that this is done and that you configured an ODBC DSN for your SAP system. For all details about installing and configuring the ODBC driver for ABAP, check my previous blog posts.

Now let’s turn to the SQL statements INSERT and DELETE and how they are supported in the SQL service.

The INSERT Statement in the SQL Dialect of the ABAP SQL Service

Compared to ABAP SQL, the SQL dialect of the SQL service has a few restrictions and specialties that  you must consider.

INSERT … VALUES and INSERT … SELECT statements are supported.

The supported INSERT … VALUES statements have the following form:

INSERT INTO <schema>.<view> VALUES ( <expression1>, <expression2>, …)

Compared to other databases, currently there is no column list clause supported. The maximum number of expressions in the VALUES clause is the number of columns in the exposed entity. If you provide fewer expressions, the last columns in the writable entity will be set to their default database values during INSERT.

Expressions can be simple literals, expressions containing functions, or parameter markers ( ‘?’ ) for prepared statements.
For literals or expressions, the types need to be compatible with the DDIC data types of exposed entity. This requires CASTs in some cases.

INSERT … SELECT statements have the following form:

INSERT INTO <schema>.<view> <ABAP SQL service SQL query>​

where <ABAP SQL service SQL query> is a SELECT statement in the SQL dialect of the SQL service.
Currently, the <ABAP SQL service SQL query> cannot contain common table expressions (CTEs starting with the keyword “WITH”).

Again, the number of columns in the result set of the SELECT statement must match the number of columns in the exposed entity, and the data types returned by the SELECT statement need to be compatible with the data types of the exposed entity.

The following INSERT statements are equivalent:

INSERT INTO <schema>.<view> VALUES ( <expression1>, <expression2>, …)

INSERT INTO <schema>.<view> SELECT <expression1>, <expression2>, … FROM SYS.DUMMY

The SYS.DUMMY trick can also be used to formulate some kind of simple SQL array INSERT:

INSERT INTO <schema>.<view>
  SELECT <expression1a>, <expression2a>, … FROM SYS.DUMMY
  UNION ALL
  SELECT <expression1b>, <expression2b>, … FROM SYS.DUMMY
  …

 I will discuss the more efficient ODBC array input method using an INSERT statement with parameter markers later with a python ODBC code sample. However, keep in mind that some ODBC tools do not support SQL statements with parameter markers or some language plugins like the node.js ODBC plugin currently do not allow to use ODBC array INSERT.

The DELETE Statement in the SQL Dialect of the ABAP SQL Service

Simple DELETE statements with or without WHERE clauses are supported.

DELETE FROM  <schema>.<view>  <WHERE-clause>

where  <WHERE-clause> can be any WHERE clause that can be used in a corresponding query (“SELECT FROM  <schema>.<view>  <WHERE-clause>”).

Bundling Multiple DML Statements in one Database Transaction

For the first time, the ABAB SQL service now supports DML statements, but it still does not provide an option for explicit transaction handling. This means that the ODBC driver for ABAP always works in auto commit mode and does not support explicit commits and rollbacks.

This implies that all DML statements are automatically committed after each successful execution. On the other hand, all changes of a DML statement execution are automatically rolled back after an error occurs.

The other way to bundle multiple row changes in a single database transaction is the use of array input for ODBC execution using DML statements with parameter markers.  Again, the ODBC execution with array input is atomically committed on success or rolled back after an error.

Without explicit transaction handling, multiple different DML statements cannot be bundled in one database transaction.

DML examples without Parameter Markers Using iusql

I will now provide some DML examples on our test entity using the simple iusql command line tool included in the Linux unixODBC package ( see my Linux blog post). This is just an arbitrary example of a tool that does not support SQL statements with parameter markers. As an alternative, you could, for example, use a Java-based tool like DBeaver or Squirrel with a suitable JDBC/ODBC bridge for the ODBC driver for ABAP.

In this example, the following happens:

  • An INSERT … VALUES statement is used to insert the first row into our test entity
  • Some INSERT … SELECT statements are used to generate more test data with ascending ItemNr and IDate
  • A DELETE … WHERE is used to delete a first set of rows
  • A subsequent DELETE is used to clean up the table

> iusql -v MYDSN

+---------------------------------------+
| Connected!                            |
|                                       |
| sql-statement                         |
| help [tablename]                      |
| quit                                  |
|                                       |
+---------------------------------------+

SQL> delete from ZWRITE.WriteView

SQLRowCount returns 0

SQL> insert into ZWRITE.WriteView
     values( 1 , date '2015-01-01' , CAST( 100 AS DECIMAL)  )

SQLRowCount returns 1

SQL> INSERT INTO ZWRITE.WriteView
     select MAX(VMAX.ItemNr) + V.ItemNr ,
     DATN_ADD_DAYS( V.IDate, MAX(VMAX.ItemNr) ) ,
     V.Amount
     from ZWRITE.WriteView V ,
          ZWRITE.WriteView VMAX
     group by V.ItemNr , V.IDate, V.Amount

SQLRowCount returns 1

SQL> repeat … INSERT INTO

SQLRowCount returns 2

SQL> repeat … INSERT INTO

SQLRowCount returns 4

SQL> repeat … INSERT INTO

SQLRowCount returns 8

SQL> repeat … INSERT INTO … make sure that you do not repeat this too often

SQLRowCount returns 16

SQL> select ItemNr, IDate FROM ZWRITE.WriteView

+------------+---------+
| ItemNr     | IDate   |
+------------+---------+
| 1          | 20150101|
| 2          | 20150102|
| 3          | 20150103|
| …                    |
| 19         | 20150119|
| 20         | 20150120|
| 21         | 20150121|
| …                    |
| 31         | 20150131|
| 32         | 20150201|
+------------+---------+

SQLRowCount returns 0

32 rows fetched

SQL> delete from ZWRITE.WriteView where IDate < date '2015-01-20'

SQLRowCount returns 19

SQL> delete from ZWRITE.WriteView

SQLRowCount returns 13


DML Array Input Examples Using a Python Sample

ODBC supports using prepared statements multiple times. Prepared statements with parameter markers can be executed with an array input, allowing to execute the same prepared statement multiple times with a different set of input parameters in one network roundtrip. For the ODBC driver for ABAP, this also means that such statement executions with array input will be performed in one database transaction and all statement executions will be committed or rolled back together.

Native ODBC C code can easily become lengthy and is not well suited for demo purposes. Therefore, like in one of my previous blog posts about AMDP procedures, I will provide a Python code sample here. Python demo code is much more compact and easier to read and understand. The Python ODBC plugin called pyodbc supports ODBC array input. A more detailed introduction to this ODBC plugin has already been provided in this Python blog post .

The following Python sample code:

  • Inserts some rows with an INSERT … VALUES statement with parameter markers
  • Doubles the number of rows with an INSERT … SELECT statement
  • Deletes some rows with an array DELETE statement with parameter markers

A subsequent DELETE is used to clean up the table

Please note fast_executemany=True used for the array statement. This ensures that the array data is sent to the ABAP backend in one package and that the array operation is performed in one database transaction.

import pyodbc
import getpass
import datetime
# some docu in
# https://code.google.com/archive/p/pyodbc/wikis/GettingStarted.wiki
# https://github.com/mkleehammer/pyodbc/wiki
#
# install pyodbc before running the program 
# "pip install pyodbc"
#
# run with
# "python3 "array_dml_demo.py"

dsn   = input("Your ODBC DSN? ")
user  = input("Your Connect User? ")
pwd   = getpass.getpass("Your Connect Password? ")

conn = pyodbc.connect('DSN=' + dsn + ';UID=' + user + ';PWD=' + pwd + ';Trace=none;' )

def truncate_data():
  truncate_curs = conn.cursor()
  sql_truncate = "DELETE FROM ZWRITE.WriteView"
  truncate_curs.execute(sql_truncate)
  row_count = truncate_curs.rowcount
  print('Number of truncated rows: ' + str(row_count) )
  truncate_curs.close()

truncate_data()

# The following test code runs on a writable view entity exposed as 
#   ZWRITE.WriteView 
# with columns
#   key itemnr : abap.int4 not null;
#   key idate  : abap.datn not null;
#   amount     : abap.decfloat34;

# array data for insert
array_data = [
    (1, datetime.date(2023, 12, 24), 17 ),
    (2, datetime.date(2023, 12, 25), 4711 ),
    (3, datetime.date(2023, 12, 26), 1995 )
]

insert_curs = conn.cursor()
insert_curs.fast_executemany = True
sql_insert_with_values_clause = "INSERT INTO ZWRITE.WriteView VALUES (?, ?, ?)"
insert_curs.executemany(sql_insert_with_values_clause, array_data)
print('Insert Array Size: ' + str(len(array_data)) )
# pyodbc always returns row_count=-1 for executemany() ?!
# https://github.com/mkleehammer/pyodbc/issues/481
# row_count = insert_curs.rowcount
# print('Number of inserted rows: ' + str(row_count) )

sql_insert_select = "INSERT INTO ZWRITE.WriteView SELECT itemnr+3, DATN_ADD_DAYS(idate , 3), amount FROM ZWRITE.WriteView"
insert_curs.execute(sql_insert_select)
row_count = insert_curs.rowcount
print('Number of inserted rows: ' + str(row_count) )
insert_curs.close()

query_cursor = conn.cursor()
sql_query = "SELECT * FROM ZWRITE.WriteView"
query_cursor.execute(sql_query)
for row in query_cursor.fetchall():
    print (row)
query_cursor.close()

delete_curs = conn.cursor()
delete_curs.fast_executemany = True
sql_delete = "DELETE FROM ZWRITE.WriteView WHERE itemnr = ? AND idate = ? AND amount = ?"
delete_curs.executemany(sql_delete, array_data)
print('Delete Array Size: ' + str(len(array_data)) )

truncate_data()

# clean up
conn.close()

The output of the program could look as follows:

> python3 array_dml_demo.py

Your ODBC DSN? MYDSN
Your Connect User? MYUSER
Your Connect Password?

Number of truncated rows: 0

Insert Array Size: 3
Number of inserted rows: 3

(1, datetime.date(2023, 12, 24), Decimal('17'))
(2, datetime.date(2023, 12, 25), Decimal('4711'))
(3, datetime.date(2023, 12, 26), Decimal('1995'))
(4, datetime.date(2023, 12, 27), Decimal('17'))
(5, datetime.date(2023, 12, 28), Decimal('4711'))
(6, datetime.date(2023, 12, 29), Decimal('1995'))

Delete Array Size: 3

Number of truncated rows: 3

Conclusion

The SQL service now allows to expose writable view entities and the blog has shown some examples of the INSERT and DELETE statements that are now supported using the ABAP SQL service.

Please provide feedback if this information has been helpful for you. I am very curious about specific use cases and about the ODBC plugins/programs you have used to implement them.

Other Blogs Related to the ABAP SQL Service or the ODBC Driver for ABAP

entry.title: Re: Order Confirmation change Output type
entry.content:
Hello @cirill0d!

The fields defined as relevant are the ones that trigger the change output when they are changed. You can choose which fields you'd like to define as relevant by configuring the following configuration activities:

  • 'Define Output Texts' (101873).
  • 'Assign Output Texts To Document Data' (101874).

The fields added on those configurations are marked as relevant, once they are changed in the document, the change output will be triggered and the texts you've defined will be shown in the change log of the form template.

Best regards,
Luiza!

Hello @Ankita_Mundhra 

Thank you for your feedback.

If your query is already running in the Integrations tab and the data is fetched successfully, you don’t need to call it again in the page logic  as long as your data variable is set to autoload and linked to that query.

Only use page logic if:

  • The variable is not set to autoload, or
  • You want to control when the data is fetched (on a button click)

Let me know if it solves 

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Principal Decrease cannot be posted to accounting after reversal
entry.content:
Reversal if Principal decrease do not create a new position flow. 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: A Social Media Mashup with Visual Cloud Functions (Part I)
entry.content: @ielsayed I will check the tutorial and get back to you. Sorry it is not working.

entry.title: Re: Principal Decrease cannot be posted to accounting aft...
entry.content:
When reversing flows, the system operates as follows: for `interest`, `initial principal increase`, or `condition-based flows`, a reversal will automatically generate a new position flow. This happens when the original position flow status changes to 'R', triggering the creation of a new position flow with the status 'S'. However, for `principal decrease` flows or flows entered under the `Other Flows` tab, the system does not automatically create a new position flow upon reversal. This is standard system logic.  

To address this, you will need to manually re-enter a new flow for any reversed principal decrease.

Hi, I had similar issue with the 'Create Component style' then I noticed that in fact you need to complete all the required steps described in the tutorial..

Preview on device

 This goal is completed when you…

  1. Download the SAP Build Apps Preview app from Apple App Store or Google Play, links can be found via the Launch section in the global toolbar at the top
  2. Log in using the code you can find in the Launch section
  3. Select and open your app from the list to view it on your mobile device

entry.title: Syntactically incompatible change of existing functionality error.
entry.content:
Hi,

In my custom code i am using the below BAPI.
Everything works fine but i get the error message which you can see in the header of the question, in ATC.
I  went through the snotes but didn't help me. (2438131, 2215852 ) 
How can i get over this issue?
Here is the BAPI.

  METHOD /bobf/if_frw_action~execute.
    TYPES: BEGIN OF lty_delivery_all,
             key     TYPE /bobf/conf_key,
             ref_doc TYPE vgbel,
           END OF lty_delivery_all.

    DATA: lt_items_all    TYPE TABLE OF /scmtms/s_tor_item_tr_k,
          lv_action_key   TYPE /bobf/conf_key,
          lt_mod          TYPE /bobf/t_frw_modification,
          ls_mod          TYPE /bobf/s_frw_modification,
          lr_action_par   TYPE REF TO /bobf/s_atf_a_create_file,
          lr_atf_root     TYPE REF TO /bobf/s_atf_root_k,
          ls_parameters   TYPE /bobf/s_atf_a_create_file,
          lt_return       TYPE TABLE OF bapiret1,
          lt_success      TYPE TABLE OF bapivbrksuccess,
          lt_delivery_all TYPE TABLE OF lty_delivery_all,
          lv_pdf          TYPE fpcontent,
          lv_destination  TYPE rfc_dest. 

    CONSTANTS: lc_x           TYPE c                       VALUE 'X',
               lc_c           TYPE c                       VALUE 'C',
               lc_ordbilltyp  TYPE fkara                   VALUE 'Z01',
               lc_ref_doc_ca  TYPE c LENGTH 1              VALUE 'K',
               lc_kschl       TYPE na_kschl                VALUE 'ZMRT',
               lc_name_prefix TYPE c LENGTH 17             VALUE 'Test',
               lc_mime_code   TYPE w3conttype              VALUE 'application/pdf',
               lc_att_type    TYPE /bobf/attachment_type   VALUE 'ATCMT',
               lc_att_schema  TYPE /bobf/attachment_schema VALUE 'DEFAULT'.

    "Get items to be able to reach delivery numbers.
    io_read->retrieve_by_association(
      EXPORTING
        iv_node        = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_node-root
        it_key         = it_key
        iv_association = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_association-root-item_tr
        iv_fill_data   = abap_true
      IMPORTING
        et_data        = lt_items_all ).

    "Prepare delivery table for all FOs.
    LOOP AT lt_items_all ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_item>) WHERE base_btd_id IS NOT INITIAL AND base_btd_tco = '73'.
      APPEND INITIAL LINE TO lt_delivery_all ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_delivery_all>).

      <ls_delivery_all>-key = <ls_item>-parent_key.
      SHIFT <ls_item>-base_btd_id LEFT DELETING LEADING '0'.
      <ls_delivery_all>-ref_doc = |{ <ls_item>-base_btd_id  ALPHA = IN }|.
    ENDLOOP.

    "Prepare data to be able to check if invoice generation should be blocked or not.
    IF lt_delivery_all IS NOT INITIAL.
      SELECT tknum,tpnum,vbeln
        FROM vttp INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_vttp)
        FOR ALL ENTRIES IN @LT_delivery_all
        WHERE vbeln = @LT_delivery_all-ref_doc.

      IF sy-subrc = 0 AND  lt_vttp IS NOT INITIAL.
        SELECT vbeln,faksk,lifsk,spstg
          FROM likp INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_likp)
          FOR ALL ENTRIES IN @LT_vttp
          WHERE vbeln = @LT_vttp-vbeln.

        IF sy-subrc = 0 AND lt_likp IS NOT INITIAL.
          SELECT vbeln,posnr,faksp,vgbel,vgpos,vgtyp
            FROM lips INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_lips)
            FOR ALL ENTRIES IN @LT_likp
            WHERE vbeln = @LT_likp-vbeln.

          IF sy-subrc = 0.
            SORT lt_lips BY vbeln posnr.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.

    "Generate attachments one by one for the selected FOs.
    LOOP AT it_key ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_key>).

      "Prepare delivery table for the current FO.
      DATA(lt_delivery) = VALUE bapivbrk_t( FOR ls_del IN lt_delivery_all WHERE ( key = <ls_key>-key ) ( ordbilltyp = lc_ordbilltyp
                                                                                                         ref_doc_ca = lc_ref_doc_ca
           	                                                                                             ref_doc    = ls_del-ref_doc  ) ).
      "Stop GAI creation in case preceding docs have blocks.
      IF lt_delivery IS NOT INITIAL.
        LOOP AT lt_delivery ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_delivery>).
          IF VALUE #( lt_likp[ vbeln = <ls_delivery>-ref_doc faksk = lc_x ]      OPTIONAL ) IS NOT INITIAL.
            DELETE lt_delivery WHERE ref_doc = <ls_delivery>-ref_doc.
          ELSEIF VALUE #( lt_likp[ vbeln =  <ls_delivery>-ref_doc lifsk = lc_x ] OPTIONAL ) IS NOT INITIAL.
            DELETE lt_delivery WHERE ref_doc = <ls_delivery>-ref_doc.
          ELSEIF VALUE #( lt_likp[ vbeln =  <ls_delivery>-ref_doc spstg = lc_x ] OPTIONAL ) IS NOT INITIAL.
            DELETE lt_delivery WHERE ref_doc = <ls_delivery>-ref_doc.
          ELSEIF VALUE #( lt_lips[ vbeln =  <ls_delivery>-ref_doc faksp = lc_x ] OPTIONAL ) IS NOT INITIAL.
            DELETE lt_delivery WHERE ref_doc = <ls_delivery>-ref_doc.
          ELSEIF VALUE #( lt_lips[ vgbel =  <ls_delivery>-ref_doc vgtyp = lc_c ] OPTIONAL ) IS NOT INITIAL.
            DELETE lt_delivery WHERE ref_doc = <ls_delivery>-ref_doc.
          ENDIF.
        ENDLOOP.
      ELSE.
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      "Create invoice.
      CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BILLINGDOC_CREATEMULTIPLE' DESTINATION lv_destination
        TABLES
          billingdatain = lt_delivery
          return        = lt_return
          success       = lt_success. "(Not optional!)

      CLEAR: lt_delivery.

      "Using the invoice number do the attachment.
      LOOP AT lt_return ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_return>).

        IF <ls_return>-type NE if_cwd_constants=>c_message_success.
          MESSAGE ID <ls_return>-id TYPE <ls_return>-type NUMBER <ls_return>-number WITH <ls_return>-message_v1 <ls_return>-message_v2 INTO lv_dummy.
          /scmtms/cl_msg_helper=>msg_helper_add_symsg( CHANGING co_message = eo_message ).
          CONTINUE.
        ENDIF.

        "Wait up to 5 seconds until the billing document is ready.
        DO 5 TIMES.
          WAIT UP TO 1 SECONDS.

          cl_o2c_bil_services=>get_print_preview(
            EXPORTING
              iv_vbeln   = CONV #( <ls_return>-message_v1 )
              iv_kschl   = lc_kschl
            IMPORTING
              ev_pdf     =  lv_pdf
              es_message = DATA(ls_msg) ).

          IF lv_pdf IS NOT INITIAL.
            EXIT.
          ENDIF.
        ENDDO.

        IF lv_pdf IS INITIAL.
          MESSAGE ID ls_msg-msgid TYPE ls_msg-msgty NUMBER ls_msg-msgno WITH ls_msg-msgv1 ls_msg-msgv2 INTO lv_dummy.
          /scmtms/cl_msg_helper=>msg_helper_add_symsg( CHANGING co_message = eo_message ).
          CONTINUE.
        ENDIF.

        "Check if there is already an attachment.
        io_read->retrieve_by_association(
          EXPORTING
            iv_node        = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_node-attachmentfolder
            it_key         = VALUE #( ( key = <ls_key>-key ) )
            iv_association = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_association-root-attachmentfolder
          IMPORTING
            et_target_key  = DATA(lt_atf_key)  ).

        "If this is the first attachment, then first create an attachment node.
        IF lt_atf_key[] IS INITIAL.
          CREATE DATA lr_atf_root.
          lr_atf_root->key        = /bobf/cl_frw_factory=>get_new_key( ).
          lr_atf_root->parent_key = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_node-root.
          ls_mod-change_mode      = /bobf/if_frw_c=>sc_modify_create.
          ls_mod-association      = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_association-root-attachmentfolder.
          ls_mod-source_node      = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_node-root.
          ls_mod-node             = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_node-attachmentfolder.
          ls_mod-source_key       = <ls_key>-key.
          ls_mod-key              = lr_atf_root->key.
          ls_mod-data             = lr_atf_root.
          INSERT ls_mod INTO TABLE lt_mod.

          io_modify->do_modify( EXPORTING it_modification = lt_mod ).
          INSERT VALUE #( key = lr_atf_root->key ) INTO TABLE lt_atf_key.
        ENDIF.

        "Fill the parameter table
        CREATE DATA lr_action_par.
        GET REFERENCE OF ls_parameters INTO lr_action_par.
        ls_parameters-alternative_name          = lc_name_prefix && <ls_return>-message_v1.
        ls_parameters-content                   = lv_pdf.
        ls_parameters-file_name                 = lc_name_prefix && <ls_return>-message_v1.
        ls_parameters-mime_code                 = lc_mime_code.
        ls_parameters-name                      = lc_name_prefix && <ls_return>-message_v1.
        ls_parameters-description_language_code = sy-langu.
        ls_parameters-description               = lc_name_prefix && <ls_return>-message_v1.
        ls_parameters-description_content       = lc_name_prefix && <ls_return>-message_v1.
        ls_parameters-visibility_type           = abap_true.
        ls_parameters-attachment_type           = lc_att_type.
        ls_parameters-attachment_schema         = lc_att_schema.

        "Get action key for creating attachment.
        IF lv_action_key IS INITIAL.
          /scmtms/cl_common_helper=>get_do_keys_4_action(
            EXPORTING
              iv_host_bo_key      = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_bo_key
              iv_host_do_node_key = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_node-attachmentfolder
              iv_do_action_key    = /bobf/if_attachment_folder_c=>sc_action-root-create_file
            IMPORTING
              ev_action_key       = lv_action_key ).
        ENDIF.

        "Attach geberated PDF.
        io_modify->do_action(
          EXPORTING
            iv_act_key    = lv_action_key
            it_key        = lt_atf_key
            is_parameters = lr_action_par
          IMPORTING
            et_failed_key = DATA(lt_failed_key_atf) ).

        "Get tor id.
        DATA(lv_tor_id) = /scmtms/cl_tor_helper_root=>return_id_fortor_key( EXPORTING iv_tor_key = <ls_key>-key ).

        "Clear for the next round.
        CLEAR: ls_parameters, lt_atf_key, lr_action_par.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

 Here is the ATC message.

Regards

entry.title: Re: Consignment Stock Update is not updated based on Ship...
entry.content:
In SAP’s design, the table MSKU (Special Stocks with Customer) will always key off the “customer” that owns the consignment—by default that is the sold-to party. There is no standard MSKU column for Ship-to, so whenever you do a Consignment Fill‐Up (KB order) the stock gets parked at the sold-to party level and that’s exactly what MB58/MB54 (or any stock‐overview) will show you.

If you truly need to record and report consignment at the ship-to level, you have two realistic options:

Make Ship-to Your “Customer” in MSKU by tweaking the partner-determination for your KB order type you can have the system treat the Ship-to party as the MSKU-customer instead of the Sold-to. Go to VOPAN  for your KB order.  In that procedure, move the Ship-to (SH) partner up above the Sold-to (SP/SB) partner.  The next time you do a Consignment Fill-Up the stock will be keyed to the ship-to party in MSKU and all standard stock reports (MB58, MB54, MMBE) will roll up on that “customer.”

Keep Sold-to in MSKU, Add a Z-Table for Ship-to If you still need Sold-to as the MSKU partner but want add’l visibility by ship-to, enhance your fill-up process with a small user-exit or BAdI. In the exit you:

  • Read the Ship-to from the order (VBPA table)
  • Write a record into a custom Z‐table (keyed by material/plant/ship-to/batch, etc.) each time you post a KB fill-up
  • Build a tiny custom Fiori/View that reads your Z‐table (and falls back to MSKU when required)

That way you preserve standard consignment‐logic, but you also capture where (Ship-to) the stock really sits and can report on it in ATP, MMBE‐style screens or bespoke apps.

Which approach fits best depends on whether you must keep the Sold-to in MSKU (for billing/legal) or whether you can replace it with the Ship-to. In most cases simply elevating SH in the partner‐determination procedure is sufficient and 100% configuration (no code) — give that a try first.

entry.title: Re: Effective way of doing an UPDATE with INNER JOIN in A...
entry.content:
With ABAP 7.50, you don't have much choice, so I would say that your solution is the easiest one, but I would select only the required columns of TABLE2 to reduce the size of the internal table:

TYPES BEGIN OF ty_data.
INCLUDE TYPE table1 AS table1.
TYPES table2_short_id TYPE table2-short_id.
TYPES END OF ty_data.

DATA lt_data TYPE TABLE OF ty_data.
DATA lt_table1 TYPE TABLE OF table1.

SELECT table1~*, table2~short_id
      INTO TABLE _data
      FROM table1
      INNER JOIN table2 ON
          table1~field1 = table2~field1
      WHERE table1~field2 IS NOT NULL.

LOOP AT lt_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_data>).
  <fs_data>-table1-short_id = <fs_data>-table2_short_id.
  INSERT <fs_data>-table1 INTO TABLE lt_table1.
ENDLOOP.

MODIFY table1 FROM TABLE lt_table1.

Another solution is to create an updatable database view with the two tables joined, with only the concerned columns (key fields and column to update) and directly update this view in ABAP. The only problem is that you can't define a view with WHERE IS NOT NULL.

A third solution, if your database is SAP HANA and you want a better performance, is to define an AMDP procedure to update via native HANA SQL (UPDATE table1 SET ... FROM ... JOIN ... WHERE ...)

NB: you may also use other native SQL solutions (ADBC, EXEC SQL), I prefer AMDP because it's best suited for organizing the code.

entry.title: Using Self-Sovereign Identity and Questionnaire Vouchers for Demand Collection
entry.content:
In the fast-evolving semiconductor industry, understanding market demand is both critical and challenging. Modern data spaces—secure, collaborative environments where multiple organizations share data—offer new opportunities for more targeted and privacy-preserving demand collection. One innovative approach combines Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) and verifiable credential (VC) vouchers to streamline questionnaire management within these data spaces, balancing control, security, and participant autonomy.Scenario Overview

Imagine a data space consisting of several semiconductor manufacturers, suppliers, and customers who share and analyze market-relevant data. A central operator is responsible for orchestrating activities such as conducting demand questionnaires. When a new demand questionnaire is to be launched, the operator:

  1. Creates the Questionnaire: The operator designs the survey and defines eligibility criteria.
  2. Selects Participants: A selected set of companies are chosen to respond, based on criteria such as region, company type, or previous participation.
  3. Issues Vouchers: For access control and tracking, the operator generates individual questionnaire vouchers, implemented as verifiable credentials (VCs).
  4. Delivers Vouchers: Each selected participant receives their unique VC voucher in their SSI wallet.
  5. Participant submits survey and uses voucher

Participants wishing to respond must not only submit the completed questionnaire but also cryptographically prove their eligibility and participation using their questionnaire voucher.

Let's break down how this system works from a technical perspective.

Implementing Questionnaire Vouchers with Self-Sovereign Identity

  1. Questionnaire Creation and Participant Selection
    1. The central operator, with authority in the data space, defines the questionnaire’s structure and the set of questions to be asked.
    2. The operator identifies a list of eligible participants (e.g., certain manufacturers or suppliers).
  2. Issuing Personalized Questionnaire Vouchers
    1. For each selected participant, the operator creates a Questionnaire Voucher VC. This digital VC attests that the holder is invited to respond to a specific questionnaire.
    2. This voucher VC may include metadata such as: Questionnaire ID, Expiry date, Participant’s organizational identifier (may be pseudonymous), Operator’s signature and issuance timestamp. The voucher VC is cryptographically signed by the operator, serving as the issuer.
  3. Distributing Vouchers via SSI Wallets
    1. Each participant has an SSI wallet—a secure application or service capable of receiving, storing, and presenting VCs.
    2. The central operator pushes the individual voucher VC to each participant’s SSI wallet, typically via secure data space messaging protocols (like DCP).
  4. Participant Submission Process: When a participant is ready to respond, the process is as follows: Identification & Eligibility Demonstration: The participant identifies with the questionnaire portal using a verifiable presentation (VP) including the  Questionnaire Voucher VC. This proves to the operator that the submission is uniquely authorized for this questionnaire and prevents duplicate or unauthorized submissions.
  5. Response Submission: The participant fills in and submits the questionnaire through the portal, attaching the required VPs. The operator’s backend verifies the voucher, ensuring only authorized participants’ responses are accepted and counted. The operator revokes the voucher VC so that it can be used only once.

 

Example Setup Guide: SSI and Questionnaire Vouchers for Demand Collection

The following guide outlines the steps for using SSI components for a demo of demand collection using Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) and questionnaire voucher verifiable credentials (VCs) in a simulated semiconductor demand forecast environment.

The scenario involves an Operator—the trusted orchestrator—and a Participants—organization invited to respond to a new market demand questionnaire.

Technical Stack

This demo spotlights the core Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) workflow for secure questionnaire access using SAP’s Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV). The example abstracts away the questionnaire application itself, focusing purely on the exchange and verification of Verifiable Credentials (VCs). The operator uses DIV to issue VCs (Membership and Questionnaire Voucher) and verify credential presentations. Each participant uses an DIV tenant to: Receive and store VCs and create verifiable presentations (VPs).

Step 0: Prerequisites

Before creating a DIV tenant, ensure that:

  • If you have not yet subscribed, go to the SAP Partner Portal and subscribe to the TDD license: SAP Partner Portal - TDD License. Once subscribed, you get an DIV entitlement. In a second step the provisioning can be triggered from SAP for Me. Therefore you need a S-User with admin rights.
  • You have the necessary administrative permissions in SAP BTP to create tenants.

... more information

Step 1: Environment Preparation – Create DIV Tenants

Operator Tenant Setup

Set up a DIV tenant for the operator with both protocol roles: „dcp-holder“ and „dcp-issuer“.

POST {provisioning_service}/api/v1.0.0/operations

Content-Type: application/json

Authorization: Bearer {token}



{

    "entity": "customer-wallet",

    "action": "provision",

    "payload":{

        "customerName": "operator",

        "customerId": "0",

        "divWalletServiceName" : "main",

        "divWalletServiceParameters": {

            "applications":[{

                "application": "sc",

                "description": "sc",

                "companies": [

                    {

                        "name": "operator",

                        "protocols" : ["dcp-holder", "dcp-issuer"]

                    }

                ]

            }

            ]

        }

    }

}

 

Publish Credential Schema

Define and publish the schemas for the required credential type (Voucher).

POST {div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/jsonSchemas
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
  "application": "sc",
  "payload": {
    "schema": {
      "jsonSchema": {
        "$id": "https://example.com/schemas/voucher-credential-schema-V2.json",
        "$schema": "https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/schema",
        "title": "SC Voucher",
        "description": "SC Voucher to submit a questionnaire",
        "type": "object",
        "properties": {
          "credentialSubject": {
            "type": "object",
            "properties": {
              "id": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "name": {
                "type": "string"
              },              
              "voucherId": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "questionnaire": {
                "type": "string"
              }            
            },
            "required": [
              "id",
              "voucherId"
            ]
          }
        }
      }
    },
    "name": "SC Voucher",
    "description": "SC Voucher"
  }
}

Configure Issuer Settings

In the operator tenant, configure the issuer to specify which credential types (voucher) it can issue, selecting the published schemas for each type.

### Get DID

GET {div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/companyIdentities

Content-Type: application/json

Authorization: Bearer {token}



### Get Issuer Configuration

GET {div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/companyIdentities/{id}/issuerConfigurations

Content-Type: application/json

Authorization: Bearer {token}



### Extend Issuer Configuration

PATCH {div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/companyIdentities/{id}/issuerConfigurations/{id}

Content-Type: application/json

Authorization: Bearer {token}



{

  "addCredentialTypes": [

  {

    "name": "voucher",

    "approvalMode": "last_vc",

    "schema": "{link to schema}"

  }]

}

 

Register Operators DID as a Trusted Issuer

To ensure the validity and trustworthiness of the issued Verifiable Credentials (VCs), it is necessary to register the issuer as a trusted issuer within the system. Only credentials issued by entities on the trusted issuer list will be recognized and accepted; this prevents the acceptance of credentials from unknown or unverified sources.

 

 

### Add issuer to trust list
POST {{div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/trustLists
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
    "application": "sc",
    "payload": {
      "name": "Operator",
      "did": "{operator DID}",
      "ignoreMissingHashlist": false,
      "credentialTypeConfiguration": [
        {
        "credentialType": "voucher",
        "autoAcceptOffers": true
        }
      ] 
    }
}

Participant Tenant Setup

For each participant, set up a DIV tenant with the protocol role: „dcp-holder“ (to receive and hold VCs and create presentations). Participants do not require issuer capabilities or schema configuration—only the ability to receive credentials and generate verifiable presentations.

### Provision DIV Wallet
#  operation_req
POST {provisioning_srv}/api/v1.0.0/operations
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
    "entity": "customer-wallet",
    "action": "provision",
    "payload":{
        "customerName": "Participant 1",
        "customerId": "1",
        "divWalletServiceName" : "main",
        "divWalletServiceParameters": {
            "applications":[{
                "application": "sc",
                "description": "sc",
                "companies": [
                    {
                        "name": "Participant 1",
                        "protocols" : ["dcp-holder"]
                    }
                ],
                "trustedIssuers": [{
                    "name" : "operator",
                    "did" : "{operator_did}",
                    "credentialTypeConfiguration": [
                        {
                        "credentialType": "voucher",
                        "autoAcceptOffers": true
                        }
                    ]
                }]
            }]
        }
    }
}

 

Step 2: Issue and Offer Verifiable Credentials

The operator is responsible for generating vouchers credentials for the participants. Once created, these credentials will be issued and offered directly to the participants. The process ensures that each participant receives a unique voucher credential, which can be later used to submit the demand questionnaire.

 

 

### Create voucher VC
POST {div _srv}/api/v2.0.0/credentials
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
    "application": "sc",
    "payload": {
        "issueWithSignature": {
            "content" : {
                "@context": [
                    "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/v1",
                    "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/examples/v1"
                ],
                "name": "Voucher for Participant 1",
                "description": "Demand submission voucher",
                "expirationDate": "2027-02-10T16:51:22.000Z",
                "type": [
                    "voucher"
                ],
                "issuer": "{Issuer DID}",
                "credentialSubject": {
                    "id": "{Holder DID}",
                    "name": "Participant 1",
                    "voucherId": "1234",
                    "questionnaire": "Demand 2026"
                },
                "credentialStatus": {
                    "id": "{revocation list}",
                    "type": "StatusList2021"
                },
                "credentialSchema": {
                    "id": "{schema link}",
                    "type": "JsonSchema"
                }
            },
            "signature" : {
                "proofMechanism" : "external", 
                "proofType" : "jwt"
            }
        }
    }
}

### Offer VC to Participant
POST {div_ srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialOffers/send
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
  "credentials": [
    "{vc id}"
  ]
}

 

Step 3: Participant Presents VCs for Questionnaire Submission

Participant presents the required voucher VC as a verifiable presentation (VP). Therefore the participant has to create a verifiable presentation including the VC.

 

### Get Credentials
GET {div _srv}/api/v2.0.0/credentials
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

### Create VP
POST {div _srv}/api/v2.0.0/presentations
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
  "application": "sc",
  "payload": {
    "prove": {
      "@context": [
        "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/v1",
        "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/examples/v1"
      ],
      "type": [
        "QuestionnairePresentation"
      ],
      "holder": "{Participants DID}",
      "proofFormat": "jwt",
      "verifiableCredential": [
        {
          "jwt": "{Membership VC as JWT}"
        },
        {
          "jwt": "{Voucher VC as JWT}"
        }             
      ],
      "aud": "{Operator DID}"
    }
  }
}

 

Step 4: Operator Verifies the Verifiable Presentation

The participant submits a Verifiable Presentation (VP) to the operator. The operator then validates the included Verifiable Credential (voucher) by performing the following checks: verifying that each VC has not been revoked, confirming that each VC was issued by a trusted issuer, ensuring that all VCs are still within their validity period (not expired), and validating the cryptographic signature on the presentation. Only if all these checks are successfully passed is the VP accepted.

 

### Verify VP
POST {div_ srv}/api/v2.0.0/presentations/
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
  "application" : "sc",
  "payload" : {
    "verify" : {
      "presentation" : "{presentation}"
    }
  }
}

 

Step 5: Operator Revokes Used Voucher

After a voucher is used, its associated verifiable credential is immediately revoked. This revocation ensures that the credential cannot be verified successfully a second time, thus preventing reuse or fraudulent redemption attempts.

PATCH {{div_wallet_srv}}/api/v2.0.0/credentials/{{vc.response.body.data.0.id}}
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {{get_xsuaa_token.response.body.access_token}}

{
    "payload" : {
        "revoke" : true
    }
}

Conclusion

By leveraging the power of Self-Sovereign Identity and verifiable credentials, questionnaire-driven demand collection in semiconductor data spaces becomes both secure and flexible. The voucher-based approach ensures invitations can’t be spoofed or misused, and that only intended participants contribute to strategic market analyses. As data sharing ecosystems mature, patterns like these will be crucial for trustworthy, privacy-preserving collaboration across industry boundaries.

 

References

  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Dataspaces
  • SAP help: Documentation of the DIV Provisioning Service
  • API documentation

entry.title: How to Integrate SAP Warehouse Management with Quality Management – Full Process Flow
entry.content:
Why WM-QM Integration in SAP?

In SAP, integrating Warehouse Management (WM) with Quality Management (QM) ensures seamless coordination between logistics and quality control during material movements. When materials arrive in the warehouse, they often need to undergo quality inspection before being released for use or sale.

Without Integration:

  • Inspection lots are handled separately from warehouse stock
  • Manual tracking is required for inspection samples and blocked stock
  • Risk of errors and delays in material availability increases

With WM-QM Integration:

  • Inspection stock is automatically directed to quality bins in the warehouse.
  • Transfer Orders (TOs) are created and confirmed in sync with inspection results.
  • Warehouse and quality teams work in a unified, automated process, improving accuracy, compliance, and efficiency

Conclusion: Materials flow through the warehouse with built-in quality checks, ensuring only approved stock is put away for consumption or delivery.

SAP WM - QM Integration: Step-by-Step Process

Step 1: Define Inspection Sample Model

Path: SPRO > Logistics Execution > Warehouse Management > Interfaces > Define Quality Management > Define Inspection Sample Control

Key Settings:

  • QM Control Indicator: Determines where the inspection sample is managed (sample bin, GR area, warehouse, or skipped).
  • Inspection Bin: Manual or strategy-based bin for storing inspection samples.
  • Sample Handling: Determines how inspection samples are processed.
  • Rounding Option: Round off samples to full pallet if needed.

Step 2: Assign Quality Control Indicator to Storage Type Search

Path: Logistics Execution > Warehouse Management > Interfaces > Define Quality Management > Activate QM Interim Storage Type Search

This links the Quality Control Indicator with the Storage Type Search, allowing the system to identify the correct storage type during GR.

Step 3: Define Storage Type Search

Path: SPRO > Logistics Execution > Warehouse Management > Interfaces > Define Quality Management > Define Storage Type Search (As Necessary)

Purpose: Determines to which storage type a material should be moved during putaway, using the Storage Type Indicator.

Step 4: Create Product/Material Master (App: Manage Product Master/Create Material)

Actions:

  1. Ensure Quality Management view is maintained.
  2. Activate Post to Inspection Stock
  3. Example: Material WMQMTSTMAT created with relevant QM and WM views

 

Quality Management view in Material Master

Step 5: Create Purchase Order (App: Manage Purchase Orders/ME21N)

Details:

  1. PO created with QM relevant material
  2. Due to QM activation, stock will automatically be posted to Quality Inspection stock during GR.

Step 6: Post Goods Receipt (App: Post Goods Movement/MIGO)

System Behaviour:

  1. Stock moves to Inspection Stock at IM Level
  2. Warehouse stock is placed in GR zone/interim storage bin

Stock Overview at IM Level

Stock Overview at WM Level

Step 7: Convert Transfer requirement to Transfer Order (LT06/LT04)

Purpose: Trigger warehouse movement by converting the TR into a TO.

Step 8: Confirm the Transfer Order (App: LT12)

Action: TO confirmation moves stock to quality inspection bin in warehouse

Stock Movement at WM level

Step 9: Perform Quality Inspection (App: QA32)

Tasks:

  1. Inspect the Material
  2. Make the usage decision
  3. System moves the stock from inspection to unrestricted (based on usage decision)

Check stock at IM level

Since stock transfer happened, in warehouse posting change notice has been created.

Display TO

Step 10: Confirm Post-Inspection TO (App: LT12)

Action: Confirm the TO created by the system when the stock is released from QI.

Stock now available in unrestricted stock at WM level

Step 11: Perform Bin-Bin Transfer (App: LT10)

Action: Optional movement of stock from one bin to another (within the warehouse)

Check stock at WM level

If you found this guide helpful, don’t miss my other SAP MM blogs covering real-world automation, configuration tips, and best practices for procurement and inventory management.

Click to view other SAP MM WM Blogs - SAP Community

 

Regards,

Leelamohan
